By MICHAEL WEISSMAN
Homewood's anti-war movement
is warming up.
A group of fifteen students and
professors met recently to plot out
a petition drive on campus in
support of a "People's Peace
Treaty" negotiated by a National
Student Association delegation to
Vietnam and Paris, December,
1970.
The National Student Association
"neogitated" a peace treaty which
is presented in the petition.
The People's Treaty, which
supports the National Liberation
Front's peace position, calls for an
immediate U.S. - Vietcong ceasefire and a timetable for U.S.
withdrawal. The petition also asks
that those who sign the pledge
agree "to take whatever actions
appropriate to implement the
terms of the treaty."
"The treaty has met with a much

broader constituency than were
willing to call for an end to the war
last spring," said Dr. Steve Mann,
Education, a member of the
sponsoring group.
According to junior Mark
Forester, another member of the
group, signatures on the treaty are
coming in at the rate of 50 per day,
with more than 200 names by
Wednesday.
The sponsoring group consists of
people left over from last year's
Strike Committee, according to
Forester. Their first meeting was
instigated by Mike Ornstein, a grad
student and a member of the New
University Conference which
already supported the People's
Treaty.
"The aim of the group is first to
saturate Hopkins with the treaty
and then see what happens," said
Forester.

ESP; or Extra-Sensory Pollution
Physicists tell us there are three basic forces at work in the universe: matter, energy and chopped liver.
But I, for one, am no longer satisfied with this narrow definition.
How do physicists classify ESP? Certainly it falls into none of these
categories, hut just as certainly it exists. And not as a mere theory; ESP
is a proren, demonstrated fact.
For example, how many times have you walked into a place you
never saw before and yet recog ized everything? How many times have
you known the exact words someone was going to say before he ever
said them? How many times have you been absolutely certain something was going to happen hundreds or even thousands of miles awaY
and, sure enough, it did?
Let me tell you about a case I am fortunately able to document.
Some years ago I went fishing with my dear friend Donald L. Fromkiss
at a virgin lake deep in the Canadian wilds. It was hellishly difficult to
get there, but we did not mind, for the moment we dropped our lines
we each caught a splendid crappie. Mine weighed just over :300 pounds.
Donald's was somewhat smaller, but by far the friendlier.
Imagine my surprise then when, before we could throw our lines
back for another try, Donald suddenly leaped up and cried he'd had a
premonition that he must go home immediately. He could not tell me
why. He only knew that some one or some thing was calling him back
and he had to go at once. Apologizing profusely, he left me alone on
the lake and portaged to the nearest town (Moose Jaw, well over a
thousand miles, and poison sumac every inch), and there he chartered
a Ford Tri-Motor and flew home.
Well sir, at first he felt like an utter dolt. Everything was perfectly
normal at home. His wife Edith was quietly reading The Sensuou.<
Woman. His son Herschel was taking his daily glassblowing lesson his dog Trey was eating his leash.
And yet the premonition would not leave Donald. Carefully, he
went through the house, inch by inch, room by room. Sure enough,
when he got to the back hall he suddenly heard a faint whimpering
noise outside. He flang open the door. And there, by George, he saw
where the whimpering was coming from: someone had left a basket oo
the back stoop!
Well sir, who can blame Donald for crying a cry of joy and triumph? What a find! A whimpering basket! That's something you don't
see every day, let me tell you!
And so today, as you know of course, Donald L. Fromkiss and
His Whimpering Basket is one of the highest paid acts in show business. Next Sunday, in fact, he completes his 84th consecutive year on
Ed Sullivan.

North Towards War
When the noted foreign policy expert Hans
Morganthau was here for Commemoration Day
ceremonies last week, he remarked privately that he
thought the next step in the war would be an invasion of
the North. "What else?" he wanted to know. American
Presidents are still unwilling to "lose." All they can do
is "let loose." And where else can you go once you've
wasted South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos? Why,.
North, of course.
Yesterday's news dispatches from Washington and
Saigon lend awesome credence to Morganthau's
forecast. South Vietnamese President Thieu, out talking
to the people, told them it would be "only a matter of
time" before an invasion of the North. And President
Nixon,in his foreign policy address to Congress, pledged
as usual to maintain troop withdrawals while expanding
the war. He said the U.S. would be faced with difficult
choices. Every day the President makes the foundation
for a sustained effort more solid.
He should remember one thing. It's spring. And while
the anti-war movement tries to get going on the
campuses and in the cities, the Nixon Administration is
letting loose as usual on the plains and jungles of
Indochina. Unfortunately, the Administration works full
time. Even more unfortunately, few of us work at all.

Paying Later?
Within the next two years Homewood will inherit
responsibility for the salaries of 23 full-time professors
that were formerly paid from foundation money. The
tab for these professors (eight per cent of the total
faculty on campus) will be $500,000 annually. The shock
of this sudden monetary blow will ensure a sizable Arts
and Sciences deficit through much of the seventies.
How did this happen? All indications point to the
Academic Council, which adamantly guards its right to
exclusively select all faculty appointments. In the early
60's foundation grants were awarded to the Social
Relations Department and the McCollum -Pratt
Institute (a biology research center) for a ten-year
period. According to knowledgeable sources, in those
prosperous days the Academic Council accepted any
money that was available with little interest in its future
impl:-..ations. So two dozen assistant, associate and full
professors were hired by the Council, and now, when the
grants run out with no replacements, the chickens have
indeed come home to roost.
The $500,000 bill could force another tuition hike of
$200. And for what?--to support two departments which
have a history of flagrantly ignoring undergraduates.
The Social Relations Department, although it lists 22
faculty members, does not permit undergraduate
majors, and by now everybody should be aware that the
Biology Department has not lived up to its teaching
obligations by any standards.
Currently federal money is easily available in
environmental engineering, social anthropology,
oceanography and biology. Some of these departments
could double in size with the influx of federal funding.
But immediate questions remain: Is this the time for
Hopkins to strongly concentrate in the ecology field? If
so, should the hired professors be asked to teach as well
as research, and what arrangements can be worked out
to insure that the school is not socked with another half
million dollar bill after ten years?
It is the responsibility of the Academic Council to
invite other faculty members, students and
administrators to openly discuss these problems.
Perhaps then the twelve professors on the Council can
better avoid the disastrous mistakes of their
predecessors while still maintaining Hopkins' position
in the vanguard of research.

North Towards War
When the noted foreign policy expert Hans
Morganthau was here for Commemoration Day
ceremonies last week, he remarked privately that he
thought the next step in the war would be an invasion of
the North. "What else?" he wanted to know. American
Presidents are still unwilling to "lose." All they can do
is "let loose." And where else can you go once you've
wasted South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos? Why,.
North, of course.
Yesterday's news dispatches from Washington and
Saigon lend awesome credence to Morganthau's
forecast. South Vietnamese President Thieu, out talking
to the people, told them it would be "only a matter of
time" before an invasion of the North. And President
Nixon,in his foreign policy address to Congress, pledged
as usual to maintain troop withdrawals while expanding
the war. He said the U.S. would be faced with difficult
choices. Every day the President makes the foundation
for a sustained effort more solid.
He should remember one thing. It's spring. And while
the anti-war movement tries to get going on the
campuses and in the cities, the Nixon Administration is
letting loose as usual on the plains and jungles of
Indochina. Unfortunately, the Administration works full
time. Even more unfortunately, few of us work at all.

Paying Later?
Within the next two years Homewood will inherit
responsibility for the salaries of 23 full-time professors
that were formerly paid from foundation money. The
tab for these professors (eight per cent of the total
faculty on campus) will be $500,000 annually. The shock
of this sudden monetary blow will ensure a sizable Arts
and Sciences deficit through much of the seventies.
How did this happen? All indications point to the
Academic Council, which adamantly guards its right to
exclusively select all faculty appointments. In the early
60's foundation grants were awarded to the Social
Relations Department and the McCollum -Pratt
Institute (a biology research center) for a ten-year
period. According to knowledgeable sources, in those
prosperous days the Academic Council accepted any
money that was available with little interest in its future
impl:-..ations. So two dozen assistant, associate and full
professors were hired by the Council, and now, when the
grants run out with no replacements, the chickens have
indeed come home to roost.
The $500,000 bill could force another tuition hike of
$200. And for what?--to support two departments which
have a history of flagrantly ignoring undergraduates.
The Social Relations Department, although it lists 22
faculty members, does not permit undergraduate
majors, and by now everybody should be aware that the
Biology Department has not lived up to its teaching
obligations by any standards.
Currently federal money is easily available in
environmental engineering, social anthropology,
oceanography and biology. Some of these departments
could double in size with the influx of federal funding.
But immediate questions remain: Is this the time for
Hopkins to strongly concentrate in the ecology field? If
so, should the hired professors be asked to teach as well
as research, and what arrangements can be worked out
to insure that the school is not socked with another half
million dollar bill after ten years?
It is the responsibility of the Academic Council to
invite other faculty members, students and
administrators to openly discuss these problems.
Perhaps then the twelve professors on the Council can
better avoid the disastrous mistakes of their
predecessors while still maintaining Hopkins' position
in the vanguard of research.

By MICHAEL MOLINA
"Our section is just as good.
as any other section in this
city, and we want it!" So went
the testimony of Wilkens
Avenue resident Bruce Voge
in a federal highway corridor
location hearing at Cardinal
Gibbons High School last
week.
The highway that threatens
the homes of Voge and some
30 neighboring families, a
road that has been on the
drawing boards for over a
decade, will be the junction of
interstate 95 from New York
City to Washington, D.C. At
present traffic must use the
Beltway or the Harbor
Tunnel.
The expressway cuts from
west to east through Leakin
Park, the Gwynns Falls
valley, the Rosemont section
and Western Cemetery. It
passes 1000 feet north of Fort
McHenry and eventually
joins the J. F. Kennedy
Highway. Another segment
continues the Jones Falls
expressway south, passing
through Fells Point.
The highway will displace
homes and industry in its
path and its proposed
construction has been the
subject of numerous federally
required public hearings over
the past few years.
Some citizens in or near the
path of the road object to any
expressway construction at
all. Mrs. Betty Sommers,
head of MAD (Movement
Against Destruction),
charged, "These highways
have always been badly

determined by the traffic
